title: Classification of current density vector map using transformer hybrid residual network
description: The classification of the current density vector map (CDVM) reconstructed from magnetocardiogram (MCG) is an important indicator for assessing cardiac function and state in clinical diagnosis. Given the limited widespread application of MCG, research on CDVM …
abstract: This article discusses the classification of current density vector maps (CDVM) obtained from magnetocardiograms (MCG) using a transformer hybrid residual network. The accurate classification of CDVM is crucial for evaluating cardiac function. With the limited application of MCG, this research aims to improve the classification process of CDVM, which is vital for clinical diagnosis and understanding cardiac states. The proposed network model offers a promising approach to enhance the classification accuracy of CDVM, benefiting the field of cardiac health assessment and diagnosis.

title: Tracing low-level structures in cryo-electron tomography
description: Cryo-electron tomography is an imaging technique that provides 3D images (tomograms) in situ of cells with sub-nanometer resolution. Typically, the first step in the analysis is to classify the tomogram voxels into different structures, named semantic segment…
abstract: This article focuses on tracing low-level structures in cryo-electron tomography, a technique providing 3D images of cells with sub-nanometer resolution. The initial analysis involves classifying tomogram voxels into distinct structures, known as semantic segments. This process is crucial for understanding cellular organization at a detailed level. By identifying and tracing these structures, researchers can gain insights into the intricate architecture of cells, contributing to advancements in cell biology and biomedical research.

title: Constructing the human brain metabolic connectome with MR spectroscopic imaging reveals cerebral biochemical organization

title: AI found a way to stop a virus before it enters cells
description: Researchers discovered a hidden molecular “switch” that herpes viruses rely on to invade cells. By combining AI, simulations, and lab experiments, they identified and altered a single amino acid that shut down viral entry. What once might have taken years was…
abstract: Researchers utilized AI, simulations, and lab experiments to uncover a molecular "switch" crucial for herpes viruses to invade cells. This innovative approach, which could have traditionally taken years, offers promising insights into combating viral infections at the cellular level.

title: A psycho-ecological signal recognition framework for user behavior prediction on digital media platforms
description: Background Digital media usage has become an integral part of daily life, but prolonged or emotionally driven engagement—especially during late-night hours—may lead to concerns about behavioral and mental health. Existing predictive systems fail to account fo…
abstract: This article introduces a psycho-ecological signal recognition framework for predicting user behavior on digital media platforms. title: Motion-corrected eye tracking improves gaze accuracy during visual fMRI experiments
description: Head movements during eye tracking in fMRI frequently distort gaze signals. This paper presents motion-corrected eye tracking, a method that corrects head motion-induced errors to produce accurate gaze data in fMRI experiments.

The study highlights the significance of accurate gaze data in fMRI research and demonstrates the benefits of implementing motion correction techniques for more reliable results.

title: Origami style lunar rover wheel expands to climb steep caves
description:

abstract: A transformable airless wheel for small lunar rovers, developed by a joint team from KAIST and UEL, enables easier access to steep lunar caves. The innovation addresses the need for improved mobility in lunar exploration, offering potential for enhanced exploration capabilities in extraterrestrial environments.

title: AI data centers are forcing obsolete 'peaker' power plants back into service

This shift highlights how the rise of AI technology is influencing energy infrastructure decisions, leading to the revival of previously considered obsolete power plants.

title: A bursting bubble would be great for AI
description: AI’s rapid expansion is fuelled by massive infrastructure spending, but real progress often comes from scarcity, not abundance. When resources tighten, innovation tends to accelerate, as seen in past energy and agricultural crises. A cooling AI investment bub…
abstract: The article discusses how a bursting bubble in AI investment could actually benefit the industry by fostering innovation through scarcity rather than abundance. It draws parallels to past crises in energy and agriculture that have accelerated innovation during times of resource constraints. The emphasis is on how limitations can drive progress in AI development, suggesting that a shift away from excessive infrastructure spending could lead to more meaningful advancements in the field.

title: Age-dependent patterns of cardiac complexity unveiled by topological data analysis of pediatric heart rate variability
description: Heart rate variability (HRV) is a well-established marker of autonomic regulation and undergoes profound maturation during early human development. In this study, topological data analysis (TDA) is applied to investigate the evolving geometric complexity of H…

title: Integrated multi-omics analysis reveals necroptosis-related biomarker BIRC3 for early diagnosis and therapeutic targeting in preeclampsia
description: Background Preeclampsia (PE) is a life-threatening pregnancy disorder lacking reliable early biomarkers. While apoptosis is implicated in PE pathogenesis, the role of regulated necrotic cell death (necroptosis) remains poorly understood. This study aimed to i…
abstract: This article presents findings from an integrated multi-omics analysis focusing on necroptosis-related biomarker BIRC3 for early diagnosis and therapeutic targeting in preeclampsia. Preeclampsia, a dangerous pregnancy condition with limited early biomarkers, has been linked to both apoptosis and necroptosis. The study sheds light on the significance of necroptosis in preeclampsia pathogenesis and proposes BIRC3 as a potential biomarker for timely intervention strategies. These insights could lead to improved diagnostic and treatment approaches for preeclampsia, offering new avenues for research and clinical practice.

title: Silicognition ManT1S ESP32 board supports T1S single-pair Ethernet for robotics and automation (Crowdfunding)

The integration of SPE in this board enhances connectivity options for robotics and automation applications, catering to the evolving needs of these industries.

title: Probabilistic greedy algorithm solver using magnetic tunneling junctions for traveling salesman problem
description: Solving a task of optimal route search may be challenging for conventional algorithms. Here, authors use tunable random signals from magnetic tunnel junctions to improve a probabilistic greedy Traveling Salesman Problem solver to better balance exploration an…

This innovative method offers potential improvements in solving complex optimization problems efficiently.

title: What is multi-access edge computing? Benefits and use cases
description: Multi-access edge computing (MEC) is a network architecture concept that brings cloud computing capabilities and IT services closer to the edge of the network, where data is generated and consumed.
abstract: Multi-access edge computing (MEC) is a network architecture concept that brings cloud computing capabilities and IT services closer to the edge of the network, where data is generated and consumed. This technology offers benefits such as reduced latency, improved network efficiency, and enhanced user experience. MEC has various use cases across industries, including augmented reality, Internet of Things (IoT) applications, and real-time video analytics, highlighting its importance in enabling advanced and responsive edge computing solutions.

title: Enhancing liveability and resilience in cities
abstract: This article discusses the importance of smart city technologies in enhancing liveability and resilience in cities. The article underscores the necessity of incorporating smart technologies for building sustainable and efficient urban environments that prioritize the well-being of residents and enhance overall resilience.

abstract: The Urban Exchange Podcast, a collaboration between SmartCitiesWorld and the Resilient Cities Network, features discussions between city leaders and industry experts on solving urban challenges. title: Special Reports
abstract: This article discusses various aspects of AI implementation in cities to enhance government services, sustainability, and citizen experiences. It covers insights from Manchester, Tampere, Dublin, Madrid, and Quezon City on innovative projects and strategies for responsible AI adoption. The focus is on clean energy, digital twins, traffic management, and resilience measures. The article emphasizes the importance of AI in urban planning and service improvement.

title: ST Engineering to provide smart city platform for Lusail City
abstract: ST Engineering has been awarded a S$60m contract to develop a smart city platform for Lusail City, Qatar, integrating advanced AI and data-driven technologies. The project aims to enhance citywide operations and management through AI, machine learning, and data analytics, improving the quality of life for 450,000 residents and visitors. This initiative signifies a significant move towards Lusail's transformation into a fully integrated smart city, emphasizing sustainability and efficiency. The partnership between ST Engineering and Lusail Real Estate Development Company highlights a commitment to delivering cutting-edge solutions for urban environments, positioning Lusail as a model smart city regionally and globally.

title: The threat of urban canyons to autonomous vehicles
abstract: Autonomous vehicles face signal black-out risks in urban canyons due to the proliferation of skyscrapers and urban development. Oxbotica warns that GPS disruptions in these areas could impact AV safety and operations. The increasing number of tall buildings contributes to this issue, necessitating a shift towards using alternative technologies like radars, cameras, and lasers for navigation. Overreliance on GPS in urban environments can lead to significant challenges for AVs, emphasizing the importance of diversifying navigation methods to mitigate risks.
